occurrences.line_text: Ne scarse good morsell all his life did tast,
Some with their eyes the daintest morsels chose;
For th'heuens the[m]selues, whence mortal men implore
And with his mortal steel quite throgh the body strooke.
Behold the image of mortalitie,
And rare perfection in mortalitie,
All be he subiect to mortalitie,
And vaine assurance of mortality,
To her fraile mansion of mortality.
Pointed with mortall sting. Of her there bred
Did neuer mortall eye behold such heauenly grace.
In many folds, and mortall sting implyes.
Th'amazed vulgar tels of warres and mortall fight.
And hides for shame. What wit of mortall wight
The hight of three the tallest sonnes of mortall seed.
His mortall mace, wherewith his foemen he dismayde.
O hold thy mortall hand for Ladies sake,
Thereby his mortall blade full comely hong
Ne might of mortall eye be euer seene;
To wreake the guilt of mortall sins is bent,
What mortall wight could euer beare so monstrous blow?
With mortall steele him smot againe so sore,
That blisse may not abide in state of mortall men.
And mortall life gan loath, as thing forlore,
His mortall life he learned had to frame
The mortall sting his angry needle shot
And tell the secret of your mortall smart;
With strokes of mortall steele without remorse,
And mortall vengeaunce ioyne to crime abhord?
Hath great or glorious in mortall eye.
And told the storie of the mortall payne,
And with stiffe force shaking his mortall launce,
And soueraine moniment of mortall vowes,
Nor voyce sound mortall; I auow to thee,
Trompart forth stept, to stay the mortall chaunce,
Of which in me yet stickes the mortall sting,
That mortall hands may not withstand his might,
Or where hath he hong vp his mortall blade,
The mortall steele despiteously entayld
Are mortall men so fond and vndiscreet,
Behold, thou Faeries sonne, with mortall eye,
Ne mortall steele emperce his miscreated mould.
Which mortall Princes wore, whiles they on earth did rayne.
Mortall Samnitis, and Cicuta bad,
And mortall arrowes, wherewith he doth fill
That through his thigh the mortall steele did gryde:
Thousand times fairer then her mortall hew,
The one imperfect, mortall, foeminine;
Three ages, such as mortall men contriue,
Ne can deuized be of mortall wit;
Which to preuent, the Prince his mortall speare
That could not die, yet seem'd a mortall wight,
Of mortall life the leafe, the bud, the flowre,
That mortall puissance mote not withstond:
And proue his cause. With that her mortall speare
Yshrowded was, and euery mortall wight
The mortall steele stayd not, till it was seene
The time, that mortall men their weary cares
That ouer mortall minds hast so great might,
Of mortall Syre, or other liuing wight,
That mortall speare she in her hand did take,
All suddenly with mortall stroke astownd,
So tickle be the termes of mortall state,
Had she not bene deuoyd of mortall slime,
We mortall wights, whose liues and fortunes bee
That mortall men her glory should admire
And sendeth forth to liue in mortall state,
Fleshly corruption, nor mortall paine.
And mortall miseries doth make her play.
As an immortall mote a mortall wight,
But she a mortall creature loued best:
Then he would make himselfe a mortall wight;
But minds of mortall men are muchell mard,
And day and night afflicts with mortall paine,
A mortall bow and arrowes keene did hold,
From mortall vew, and wrap in darkenesse dreare;
And fiercely forth her mortall blade she drew,
So mortall was their malice and so sore,
The mortall point most cruelly empight:
Vnto her natiue home from mortall miserie.
And there made gods, though borne of mortall berth,
So mortall foes so friendly to agree,
That mortall foes doe turne to faithfull frends,
And weend no mortall creature she should bee,
That yet of mortall stroke the stound doth beare.
Her mortall arrowes she at him did threat,
Such mortall malice, wonder was to see
And there his mortall part by great mischance
It was no mortall worke, that seem'd and yet was not.
The which, more eath it were for mortall wight,
But for he was halfe mortall, being bred
Of mortall sire, though of immortall wombe,
Which being ment of mortall creatures sead,
Of a late wrong vppon a mortall foe;
For she her selfe professeth mortall foe
Vpon the thrones of mortall Princes tend,
With so huge rigour, that his mortall speare
The which with mortall malice him pursu'd so nere.
For whom they wayted as his mortall fone,
Into the mindes of mortall men doe well,
With that his mortall hand a while he stayd,
Such is the weakenesse of all mortall hope;
And body haue receiu'd a mortall wound,
He knew the diuerse went of mortall wayes,
All were it to his mortall enemie,
But loe the Gods, that mortall follies vew,
Liker to heauen, then mortall wretchednesse.
To weet what mortall hand, or heauens grace
But most of them were tongues of mortall men,
To mortall men, then he had done before;
Whilest here on earth she liued mortallie.
Whom mortally he hated euermore,
Had power to staunch al wounds, that mortally did bleed.
Full many strokes, that mortally were ment,
His cruell hand, to smite him mortally,
Charg'd with his speare and mortally did wound,
And droue away the stound, which mortally attacht him.
Gay steed with spurs did pricke, the good Sir Mortdant was.
Which cunningly was without morter laid,
How mortgaging their liues to Couetise,
And proud rebellious flesh to mortify.
Their armes abroad, with gray mosse ouercast,
And with greene mosse cou'ring her nakednesse,
With woody mosse bedight, and all his steed
But the bare ground, with hoarie mosse bestrowed,
Vnmard with ragged mosse or filthy mud;
Couered with mossie shrubs, which spredding brode
Vnder the foot of Rauran mossy hore,
The mossy braunches of an Oke halfe ded.
For mossy trees, which couered all with shade
Whom that most noble Briton Prince so long
And thou most dreaded impe of highest Ioue,
Which of all earthly things he most did craue;
That path they take, that beaten seemd most bare,
Most lothsom, filthie, foule, and full of vile disdaine.
That path he kept, which beaten was most plaine,
Then choosing out few wordes most horrible,
Cast a blacke stole, most like to seeme for Vna fit.
Most like that virgin true, which for her knight him took.
And in her many troubles did most pleasure take.
Of a most mighty king, most rich and sage;
Of a most mighty king, most rich and sage;
And fro me hid: of whose most innocent death
Thensforth from her most beastly companie
Yet she most faithfull Ladie all this while
O how can beautie maister the most strong,
Her that him lou'd, and euer most adord,
Then furthest from her hope, when most she weened nie.
Which euer after in most wretched case,
On which there sate most braue embellished
He leaues the welkin way most beaten plaine,
Still drownd in sleepe, and most of his dayes ded;
And all the way, most like a brutish beast,
Most wretched wight, whom nothing might suffise,
And all the while, most heauenly melody
O thou most auncient Grandmother of all,
With Elfin sword, most shamefully betrade?
But most of all, which in the Dongeon lay
And Phoebus flying so most shamefull sight,
Most sencelesse man he, that himselfe doth hate,
His mightie armour, missing most at need;
That shynd, like twinkling stars, with stons most pretious rare.
And eke her feete most monstrous were in sight;
And who most trustes in arme of fleshly might,
And yeeldes his caytiue neck to victours most despight.
Most goodly glee and louely blandishment
Most enuious man, that grieues at neighbours good,
Or from the field most cowardly doth fly?
The eldest two most sober, chast, and wise,
Most vertuous virgin borne of heauenly berth,
Loe two most goodly virgins came in place,
For them most needeth comfort in the end,
When sin, and hell, and death do most dismay
And when they stood in most necessitee,
To that most glorious house, that glistreth bright
Most trew, then said the holy aged man;
most glorious victory.
Now O thou sacred Muse, most learned Dame,
But his most hideous head my toung to tell
That erst him goodly arm'd, now most of all him harm'd.
A trickling streame of Balme, most soueraine
That who so kild that monster most deforme,
To thee, most mighty king of Eden faire,
Most false Duessa, royall richly dight,
His owne two hands, for such a turne most fit,
Right well I wote most mighty Soueraine,
That you, most noble Sir, had present beene,
Her golden lockes most cruelly she rent,
Of late most hard atchieu'ment by you donne,
The most vnruly, and the boldest boy,
And by the loues, which were to them most deare,
But louely concord, and most sacred peace
Great and most glorious virgin Queene aliue,
Order of Maydenhead, the most renownd,
And her streight legs most brauely were embayld
All vertue merits praise, but such the most of all
With that blacke Palmer, his most trusty guide;
The man most warie in her whelming lap.
Most ioyous man, on whom the shining Sunne,
Aray thy selfe in her most gorgeous geare,
Then gan the Palmer thus, most wretched man,
Varlet, this place most dew to me I deeme,
His be that care, whom most it doth concerne,
Auauntage, whilest his foe did rage most rife;
Was neuer man, who most conquestes atchieu'd
Helpe, Ã´ Sir Guyon, helpe most noble knight,
And euery of them stroue, with most delights,
As her fantasticke wit did most delight,
And at their feet her selfe most humbly feld,
Ah well away, most noble Lords, how can
Most wretched woman, and of wicked race,
The mightie martiall hands doe most commend;
That am, I weene, most wretched man aliue,
Weake hands, but counsell is most strong in age.
But most were stampt, and in their metall bare
Nath'lesse most heauenly faire in deed and vew
Most cursed of all creatures vnder skye,
But both his hands most filthy feculent,
And most vniust, that by vnrighteous
Honour is least, where oddes appeareth most.
But when he stroke most strong, the dint deceiu'd,
My Lord, my liege, by whose most gratious ayd
Of that most glorious visage ye did vew?
Braunched with gold & pearle, most richly wrought,
That Turrets frame most admirable was,
For they of liuing fire most subtilly
Of my most dreaded Soueraigne I recount,
But those three monstrous stones doe most excell
Inquyrd, which of them most did loue her parentage.
That loue is not, where most it is profest,
Most mercilesse of women, VVyden hight,
And with most cruell hand him murdred pittilesse.
Left of his life most famous memory,
Did far excell, but was most famous hight
But Elfant was of most renowmed fame,
Yet should they be most famous moniments,
And exercise most bitter tyranny
There Alma like a virgin Queene most bright,
And his contrary obiect most deface,
With which they dayly made most dreadfull battery.
But the fift troupe most horrible of hew,
Faire mote he thee, the prowest and most gent,
They reard a most outrageous dreadfull yelling cry,
So greatest and most glorious thing on ground
That was most strong in most infirmitee;
That was most strong in most infirmitee;
Into most deadly daunger and distressed plight.
Most vgly shapes, and horrible aspects,
From her most cunning hand escaped bee;
That art in mighty armes most magnifide
And rule the Furyes, when they most do rage:
There the most daintie Paradise on ground,
And that, which all faire workes doth most aggrace,
Most goodly it with curious imageree
Etfsoones they heard a most melodious sound,
Where daungers dwelt, and perils most did wonne,
Most goodly meede, the fairest Dame aliue:
That Castle was most goodly edifyde,
That truth is strong, and trew loue most of might,
Basciante did him selfe most curteous shew;
That women wont in warres to beare most sway,
The warlike ryder to his most mishap;
And what so else his person most may vaunt?
Of hurt vnwist most daunger doth redound:
Then I auow by this most sacred head
To loue the semblant pleasing most your mind,
Th'vneuen number for this businesse is most fit.
Most sacred fire, that burnest mightily
Most famous fruits of matrimoniall bowre,
From vnder that deepe Rocke most horribly rebounds.
Most noble Virgin, that by fatall lore
Braue Captaines, and most mighty warriours,
Yet during this their most obscuritee,
Daughter, I deeme that counsell aye most fit,
But most of Arthegall, and his estate.
That when he sleepes in most security,
Most sacred virgin, without spot of sin.
The bountiest virgin, and most debonaire,
Do one, or other good, I you most humbly pray.
Of whom ye seeke to be most magnifide:
The which was all within most richly dight,
But lapped vp her silken leaues most chaire,
First she him sought in Court, where most he vsed
Where most she wonnes, whe[n] she on earth does dwel.
Threw forth most dainty odours, & most sweet delight.
Threw forth most dainty odours, & most sweet delight.
But that lewd louer did the most lament
Through her maine strength, in which she most doth trust,
The fairest wight on ground, and most of men esteemed.
Of falshood or of slouth, when most it may behoue.
Most vertuous virgin, glory be thy meed,
Where most sweet hymmes of this thy famous deed
But most they meruail[e]d at her cheualree,
Most famous Worthy of the world, by whome
That bold he said; ï¿½ most redoubted Pere,
And you most noble Lord, that can and dare
Cannot employ your most victorious speare
Said Trompart, You that are the most opprest
And with most painefull pangs to sigh and sob,
There he tormenteth her most terribly,
All which in that faire arras was most liuely writ.
The whiles a most delitious harmony,
After all these there marcht a most faire Dame,
Shame most ill fauourd, bestiall, and blind:
But most faire Amoret, whose gentle spright
There did he see, that most on earth him ioyd,
To her this song most fitly is addrest,
To be most fit to trouble noble knights,
The which most often end in bloudshed and in warre.
Her face most fowle and filthy was to see,
And prou'd himselfe most foole, in what he seem'd most wise.
And prou'd himselfe most foole, in what he seem'd most wise.
And that which is for Ladies most befitting,
And of those Knights who is most stout on ground,
For vertue is the band, that bindeth harts most sure.
To weete, two Ladies of most goodly hew,
Then pardon, O most sacred happie spirit,
Most confidence and hope of happie speed,
Most wretched men, whose dayes depend on thrids so vaine.
Yet is as nigh his end, as he that most doth playne.
And to be seene, as his most worthie wage,
The mortall point most cruelly empight:
Else how could one of equall might with most,
The prize of her, which did in beautie most excell.
To stirre vp strife, when most vs needeth rest,
Most answerable to his wyld disguize
The doughtiest knight that liv'd that day, and most of might.
For he me seemes most fit the faire to serue,
And she most fit his seruice doth deserue,
In which to her that doth the most excell,
Which being once withdrawne, most perfect hew
At last the most redoubted Britonesse,
Whom, when he was vnto her selfe most nie,
The things that day most minds, at night doe most appeare.
The things that day most minds, at night doe most appeare.
But most was moued at the piteous vew
For most of strength and beautie his desire
Me seemes the gentle hart should most assured bind.
But most she touched was with griefe entire,
For though she were most faire, and goodly dyde,
Faint friends when they fall out, most cruell fomen bee.
Certes her losse ought me to sorrow most,
But seeme gainst common sence to them most sweet;
Abounding all with delices most rare,
And brauely mounted to his most mishap:
Doest fayrest shine, and most adorne thy place,
To which they all repayr'd, both most and least,
Faire Amphitrite, most diuinely faire,
There also some most famous founders were
Most voide of guile, most free from fowle despight,
Most voide of guile, most free from fowle despight,
But this to you, ï¿½ Britons, most pertaines,
Then was there heard a most celestiall sound,
Or Arts, but Oxford thine doth Thame most glorify.
Still Vre, swift Werfe, and Oze the most of might,
And Lindus that his pikes doth most commend,
For that the seas by her are most augmented.
And lowest hell, to which I lie most neare,
Most did she thinke, but most she thought amis,
Most did she thinke, but most she thought amis,
Least did she thinke, that which he most concealed,
When Iustice was not for most meed outhyred,
But most is Mars amisse of all the rest,
Most sacred vertue she of all the rest,
Whose soueraine powre is herein most exprest,
For of most perfect metall it was made,
And from the most, that some were giuen to the least?
All creatures must obey the voice of the most hie.
The bridegromes state, the brides most rich array,
The most part of my land hath washt away,
For any death to chaunge life though most bad:
But onely thus; Most haplesse well ye may
To whom she bore most feruent loue of late,
As the faire Moone in her most full aspect,
Amongst them all she placed him most low,
Her nearest handmayd, whom she most did trust,
And dare euen deathes most dreadfull face behold?
But most the knight, whom she with guilefull call
Therefore vnto her mistresse most vnkind
But most she did her troubled mynd molest,
With curteous words, in the most comely wize;
The one of them, which most her wrath increast,
Did the most chast Penelope possesse,
Her name Mercilla most men vse to call;
That with most fell despight and deadly hate,
Her selfe most gratefull shew'd, & heaped thanks repayd.
Swearing, and banning most blasphemously,
And they that most in boldnesse doe excell,
Are dreadded most, and feared for their powre:
Most sacred wight, most debonayre and free,
Most sacred wight, most debonayre and free,
Whose porch, that most magnificke did appeare,
Yet glad at last to make most base submission,
To God, to doe vnto his Idole most vntrew.
Him thus bespake; O most redoubted Knight
The which hast me, of all most wretched wight,
Most richly made, but there no Monster did behold.
Most vgly filth, and poyson therewith rusht,
Albe that it most safety to him gaue,
Made him become most faithlesse and vnsound:
And right and wrong most cruelly confound:
Most squalid garments, fit for such a day,
And did in strength most sorts of men surpas,
To doe most dammage, where as most they ment.
To doe most dammage, where as most they ment.
On whom he did inflict most grieuous punishment.
Most foule and filthie were, their garments yet
Did much the more augment, and made most vgly cases.
And at him throwes it most despightfully.
And still among most bitter wordes they spake,
Most shamefull, most vnrighteous, most vntrew,
Most shamefull, most vnrighteous, most vntrew,
Most shamefull, most vnrighteous, most vntrew,
Then pardon me, most dreaded Soueraine,
For that it there most vseth to abound;
Where curteous Knights and Ladies most did won
That shall you most renowmed make for euermore.
On hideous strokes with most importune might,
Bynding himselfe most firmely to obay,
Most ioyfully she them did entertaine,
Mongst which my most delight hath alwaies been,
Onely the vse of armes, which most I ioy,
And fitteth most for noble swayne to know,
With loud laments that most vnluckie stound,
Sith his own thought he knew most cleare from wite.
Most pensiue man, through feare, what of his childe became.
Most perfect pure, and guiltlesse innocent
Most ioyfull man her sire was her to see,
He there did make, and then most carefully
When day is spent, and rest vs needeth most,
But most for pitty of his dearest Dame,
Such was the state of this most courteous knight
That he remayned in most perilous plight,
There he this most discourteous crauen found,
But most my Lord is grieued herewithall,
But he did her attend most carefully,
Three mightie en'mies did him most despight,
But most that curre barking with bitter sownd,
But most of all Defetto him annoyde,
Who both in minde, the which most grieueth me,
Or else remained in most wretched state,
It is most straunge and wonderfull to fynd
The poysnous humour, which did most infest
From that they most affect, and in due termes containe.
Gainst all, both good and bad, both most and least,
But most the former villaine, which did lead
But that same foole, which most increast her paines,
Nor heauens, nor men can me most wretched mayd
Thereto they vsde one most accursed order,
But most of all the shepheard Coridon
Her fleecie flocke; but Coridon most helpe did giue.
As they doe know each can most aptly vse.
For not that, which men couet most, is best,
Nor that thing worst, which men do most refuse;
For wisedome is most riches; fooles therefore
That Colin Clout should pipe as one most fit;
That most in Pastorellaes grace did sit.
She vsed most to keepe her royall court,
Amidst a ring most richly well enchaced,
But most of all, those three did her with gifts endew.
Most sorrowfull, most sad, that euer sigh't,
Most sorrowfull, most sad, that euer sigh't,
And inly burnt with flames most raging whot,
Mote to them for their most commodity
And sold for most aduantage not to be forstalled.
But chiefly Calidore, whom griefe had most possest.
Most certaine markes, (sayd she) do me it teach,
And ransacke all their dennes from most to least,
But most of them were tongues of mortall men,
Ne spareth he most learned wits to rate,
With humblest suit that he imagine mot,
That liuing creature mote it not abide;
Frï¿½lissa was as faire, as faire mote bee,
O how, said he, mote I that well out find,
Good cause of mine excuse; that mote ye please
A fordonne wight from dore of death mote raise,
That of no enuious eyes he mote be spyde:
That eye mote not the same endure to vew.
Yf liuing man mote worthy be, to be her liefe.
But not so happie as mote happie bee:
And you Sir knight, whose name mote I request,
And opened his dull eyes, that light mote in them shine.
That nought mote perce, ne might his corse be harmd
Whenas no strength, nor stroks mote him constraine
Of such, as vertues like mote vnto him allye.
Then said the Redcrosse knight, Now mote I weet,
Certes (said he) well mote I shame to tell
Well mote yee thee, as well can wish your thought,
Yet algates mote he soft himselfe appease,
Of him, what mighty warriour that mote bee,
That mote him honour win, to wreake so foule despight.
But mote I wisely you aduise to doon;
And wondred in his mind, what mote that monster make.
But mote thy goodlyhed forgiue it mee,
Least by her presence daunger mote befall.
Ne euer wight, that mote so welcome bee,
Art thou now bound? for well mote I discerne
That armd with fire, more hardly he mote him withsto[n]d.
When euer his fiers hands he free mote find:
And said, and did all that mote him delight,
